column4: I'm looking to use PC Anywhere on my Ubuntu machine but it doesn't support it, it only supports SuSe and Red Hat, is there a way to make it work on Ubuntu Anyways ?
you might also want to look at nomachine and freenx for an RDP type service for Linux
does this need to reverse a tunnel over NAT?
will you have the ability to open ports to the machines like port 22?
next question; do you need the ability to work on the desktop for extended periods of time or just a quick gui from time to time
will you need to share the screen with a user on the other end?
the easiest way would be to use Gnome's VNC server: System --> Preferences --> Remote Desktop
make sure that you set the password and don't require confirmation
before or after their account is created?
this should work.  I would also look into x11vnc
go to System --> Admin --> Login Window and set up an autologon account either by time (ie. 10 seconds) or everytime
also make sure that you get ssh access to the computers.  That way you can modify the remote settings.
ssh or openssh.  It is an encrypted command line method that gives you the keys to the kingdom
In fact, I would suggest that you encrypt your remote desktop sessions over it.  Otherwise any keystroke typed and video received will be transmitted in the clear
just enable it and make gnome automatically login with a user.
